name: polyether polyols production, short chain | polyether polyols, short chain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/27869/documentation

This dataset represents the average production of 1 kg of short chain polyether polyol (MW < 1000 g/mol). Polyether polyols are polymeric organic compounds including ether groups (R-O-R) and terminal hydroxyl groups (OH). Polyether polyols are one of the precursors of polyurethane (PUR) foam, whille the wide range of properties of PUR foams is largely determined by the used polyols.;Two different classes of polyether polyols can be distinguished, i.e., (1) long-chain polyols (mainly used for producing flexible foams, combined with toluene diisocyanate) and (2) short chain polyols (mainly used for producing rigid foams, combined with methylene diphenyl diisocyanate). Long chain polyether polyols (MW > 1000 kg/kmole) are waxy solids, while short chain ones (MW < 1000 kg/kmole) are liquids.;Polyether polyols are produced by the alkoxylation process with propylene oxide and ethylene oxide being the main raw materials. The production take place in batch mode in the presence of an initiator with an OH functional group (e.g., glycerine, saccharose or other carbohydrates, is commonly used), while a potassium hydroxide (KOH) is used as catalyst. ;References:;Adam, N., Avar, G., Blankenheim, H., Friederichs, W., Giersig, M., Weigand, E., Halfmann, M., Wittbecker, F.-W., Larimer, D.-R., Maier, U., Meyer-Ahrens, S., Noble, K.-L. and Wussow, H.-G. (2005). Polyurethanes. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, (Ed.). https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a21_665.pub2;2021, ISOPA , Eco-profile of toluene diisocyanate (TDI) and methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) , 3 - SeparatePublication;2021, ISOPA , Eco-profile of long and short chain polyether polyols for polyurethane products;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - polyol production, RER, 1995 - 2001 (80d5c197-ffb3-41cf-8d31-ceaeae10e71a)]

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends once  the product, i.e., 1 kg of short chain polyether polyol, is at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2013:Manufacture of plastics and synthetic rubber in primary forms

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data collection for production was collected as 12-month averages representing the year 2018. The inventory creation and calculation stage was concluded in 2020, while the technology is not expected to change until 2026.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Representative for 80 % of the short chain polyether polyols coverage in terms of production volumes in the EU region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This inventory represents the average production of short chain polyether polyols, provided as a generic dataset. ;Polyether polyols are produced by the alkoxylation process, where ethylene oxide and propylene oxide react in the presence of an initiator with an OH functional group (e.g., glycerine, saccharose or other carbohydrates, is commonly used), while a potassium hydroxide (KOH) is used as catalyst. Notably, the amount of alkoxylation species can be varied to achieve different chain lengths and molecular weights.;In more detail, the process takes place in a batch mode, where an initiator and a base (catalyst) are first introduced. The role of the initiator and the catalyst is generate an alcoholate-anion, subsequently the epoxide is introduced and the reaction operates at approximately 100 - 130 Â°C at a pressure within the following range 2 - 5 bar. The reaction is strongly exothermic, and thus, the cooling of the reactor is important to maintain the temperature level within the latter range.;Finally, the short chain polyether polyol product has to be purified, i.e. separated from the spent catalyst, which takes place through the introduction of an acid which reacts with the base (i.e., catalyst) to form an insoluble salt which is easily removed by filtering.;References:;2021, ISOPA , Eco-profile of long and short chain polyether polyols for polyurethane products
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Small input quantities of (i) generic stabilizer, (ii) magnesium silicate, and (iii) polyether, with a representation on dry mass input lower than 0.4%, was cut-off. At the same time, glucose was used as proxy substitute for sorbitol.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Industry data, representative for 80 % of the short chain polyether polyols coverage in terms of production volumes in the EU region in 2018.

The industrial data used originate from three different polyether polyols producers with four plants in three different European countries.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA DÃ¼bendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, DÃ¼bendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) UmwelterklÃ¤rung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.;activityLink introduced to establish a direct link to the corresponding regional supply of this product
